Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and applicability of 'compelling reasons' exception
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim dismissal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence corroborating abuse was ignored by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board found adequate state protection and rejected compelling reasons exception
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate lack of state protection or compelling reasons
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's account supported by medical evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Refugee status may be denied if reasons for persecution have ceased, unless compelling reasons exist due to past persecution
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess evidence and apply legal framework
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed initially due to perceived cessation of risk
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Board's reasoning found incongruous with facts and incomplete
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical documentation of physical and sexual assaults
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, particularly provisions on cessation and compelling reasons
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Board erred in assessing state protection and severity of past persecution
Crimes.Court_Result: Remitted for re-determination by a new panel
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Past persecution due to membership in particular social group
Crimes.Applicable_Process: Refugee appeal and judicial review process

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on gender/sexual orientation-based violence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of power by law enforcement, repeated incidents
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No indication of prior criminal behavior by victim
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – non-consensual sexual acts under coercive conditions
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient medical and testimonial evidence presented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible; Board failed to justify disbelief
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to identity and history of targeting
Crimes.Risk_Type: Targeted persecution based on sexual orientation
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious bodily harm and psychological trauma
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – motivated by prejudice against LGBTQ+ individuals
Crimes.Targeted_Individual_Status: Member of particular social group (homosexual men)
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights law, Refugee Convention, IRPA
Crimes.Applicable_Statute: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms (indirectly)
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 97(1) – compelling reasons arising from past persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Initial denial of claim based on cessation and lack of compelling reasons
Crimes.Procedural_Issues: Failure to properly analyze compelling reasons exception
Crimes.Legal_Procedure: Refugee determination and federal court review
Crimes.Government_Body_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under Rule 397 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Rules

Crimes.Crime_Name: Persecution Based on Membership in a Particular Social Group
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA s. 96, s. 97(1), Refugee Convention Article 1A(2)
Crimes.Outcome: Claim initially denied, then remitted after judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Framework: 1951 Refugee Convention, Canadian domestic refugee law
Crimes.Evidence_Requirement: Subjective fear + objective basis + nexus to protected ground
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board concluded no ongoing risk and no compelling reasons
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refugee Protection Division hearing and decision
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canada – Federal Court jurisdiction over IRPA matters
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant based on sexual orientation
Crimes.Temporal_Context: Past incidents in Argentina, current assessment of future risk
Crimes.Geographic_Context: Argentina (Buenos Aires), assessed within Canadian refugee process
Crimes.Personal_Data_Implicated: Sexual orientation, health information, personal safety
Crimes.Complaint_Issues: Misapplication of law regarding cessation and compelling reasons
Crimes.Protected_Group: Particular social group: homosexual men in Argentina
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution under IRPA s. 108(4)
Crimes.Protection_Claim: Need for state protection absent in home country
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Board incorrectly found adequate state protection
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of police abuse due to sexual orientation
Crimes.Enforcement_Action: None taken to protect applicant in Argentina
Crimes.Legal_Basis: Fear of persecution linked to membership in a PSG

Crimes.Crime_Name: Cruel and Unusual Treatment or Punishment
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection involving allegations of torture or ill-treatment
Crimes.Outcome: Initial refusal overturned on judicial review
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Past exposure to cruel and degrading treatment by state agents
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Refugee protection or protection under subsection 97(1)
Crimes.Legal_Framework: UN Convention Against Torture, IRPA, Charter
Crimes.Evidence_Requirement: Clear and convincing evidence of past mistreatment
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board dismissed claim citing cessation and lack of severity
Crimes.Exemptions_or_Defenses_Cited: Cessation due to changed country conditions
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant alleging serious human rights violations
Crimes.Temporal_Context: Historical abuse with implications for future risk
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether treatment amounted to persecution or rising to level of 'compelling reasons'
Crimes.Complaint_Issues: Downplaying severity of physical and sexual abuse
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution under IRPA s. 108(4)
Crimes.Protection_Claim: Absence of effective state protection against repeat abuse
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State itself was perpetrator; no meaningful recourse
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Repeat victimization likely due to identity and institutional bias
Crimes.Targeted_Group: LGBTQ+ individuals subjected to police brutality
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Physical and psychological harm amounting to cruel treatment
Crimes.Enforcement_Action: No investigation or accountability in origin country
Crimes.Legal_Basis: Past persecution creating compelling reasons for continued protection
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Sexual orientation and vulnerability to state abuse
